questions.solution:
The given image shows X-ray Defecography.

X-ray Defecography is a fluoroscopic technique to evaluate pelvic floor prolapse, incomplete or obstructed defaecation/constipation, rectal prolapse and faecal incontinence. The technique traditionally involves fluoroscopy and barium. 

Other options:

Option A: MR defecogram is a better technique that is being used more commonly. It is shown in the image given below.



Option B: Barium swallow is used to assess the oesophagus and stomach.

Option C: CT angiography is used to assess the vasculature.

questions.text: 2. A 74-year-old female complains of lower back pain. STIR sequence MRI performed showed the Honda H sign. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Sacral insufficiency due to sacral compression fracture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female complaining of lower back pain and STIR sequence MRI showing the Honda H sign suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Sacral insufficiency due to sacral compression fracture.

Sacral insufficiency fractures are a subtype of stress fractures, which are the result of normal stresses on abnormal bone, most frequently seen in patients with osteoporosis. They are usually seen in elderly females who present with low back pain without any history of significant trauma. Risk factors include osteoporosis, rheumatoid arthritis, Paget's disease, osteomalacia, diabetes mellitus and history of radiation therapy.

A typical H-sign or Honda sign (uptake in H pattern) on Tc-99m MDP scan is shown below.



Other options:

Option B: Multiple myeloma presents with lytic punched-out lesions, mostly in the skull.

Option C: Osteomyelitis is characterised by the presence of sequestrum, involucrum, and cloacae.

Option D: Transient marrow edema syndrome is a diagnosis of exclusion and generally presents in the vertebral bodies and bones of the extremities. It is characterized by pain and increased interstitial fluid within bone marrow without an obvious cause.

questions.text: 3. A 12 year old was brought with rigidity and cognitive impairment. T2W MRI showing tiger eye sign as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the cause?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI image showing the eye of the tiger sign, is suggestive of Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN), formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz syndrome. Pantothenate kinase deficiency is the cause.

The eye of the tiger sign refers to an abnormal, low T2 signal intensity on MRI (due to abnormal accumulation of iron) in the globus pallidus, with a longitudinal stripe of high signal intensity (due to gliosis and spongiosis).

This is an autosomal recessive disorder that typically manifests in childhood, leading to spasticity, Parkinsonism, and dystonia. It is classified as a subtype of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (NBIA).

The image below shows an MRI depicting the eye of a tiger sign.



Other options:

Option B: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. Neurological features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia.

Option C: Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase.

Option D: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder. The disease predominantly affects the striatum but progresses to involve the cerebral cortex and other brain regions.

questions.text: 4. A 15-year-old boy presents with recurrent seizures. A CT done shows the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with CT showing ring-enhancing cystic lesions in the brain with an eccentric dot indicating scolex, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis is a form of cysticercosis caused by Taenia solium. It usually presents with seizures and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion.

Neurocysticercosis larvae can spread to the brain parenchyma, subarachnoid space and ventricles. The four stages of parenchymal neurocysticercosis are:

* Vesicular stage- This stage consists of a viable larva with a scolex (worm head). The cysts are thin-walled with no or little enhancement, and there is no perilesional oedema

* Colloidal vesicular stage- Ring-enhancing lesions with perilesional oedema and mass effect are seen

* Granular nodular stage- thick enhancing cyst walls and progressive surrounding oedema are seen

* Calcified nodular stage- The oedema resolves, and small calcified lesions of 2–10 mm diameter are seen

Other options:

Option B: Tuberculoma (parenchymal granulomas) can mostly occur at the junction of white and grey matter. On CT, they appear as small, rounded, solid lesions that show homogenous enhancement on contrast CT and show ring enhancement when central caseation or liquefaction occurs. MRI brain shows a conglomerate or lobulated irregular shape, ring-enhancing lesion.



Option C: Brain abscess is seen as a rim-enhancing lesion along with a history of fever.



Option D: Cerebral metastasis appears as solid rather than cystic masses.

questions.text: 5. A 35-year-old patient presented with colicky pain and is suspected to have ureteric stone. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
NCCT KUB (Non-contrast CT of the kidney, ureters, and bladder) is the best diagnostic modality for the clinical evaluation of ureteric stones.

NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of:

* Renal stones except for indinavir stones

* Ureteric stones

* Head injury

* Salivary gland stones

Other options: 

Option B: Contrast-enhanced CTs abdomen are not done for renal and ureteric stones, as non-contrast CTs provide enough visualisation. Additionally, the use of contrast material adds an additional risk of developing contrast-induced kidney injury. 

Option C: A USG KUB is less sensitive compared to an NCCT KUB, is operator-dependent, and it can be difficult to visualise mid-ureteric stones.

Option D: Ureteroscopy is an invasive test and is used for therapeutic intervention, not initial diagnosis.
